comments.text:
Well, think about it this way. How much biology does an auto mechanic need 
to know? Likewise, how much physics does a doctor need to know? The problem 
with high school level education is that its so general that its useless. 
It needs to have more specific courses to help prepare you for both college 
and/or the real world. That being said it also needs to be very flexible, 
more so than a college, because high school kids probably aren't certain 
what they want to do yet so they probably will change their minds. That 
should be fine.   

Social studies is a bit iffy, because its so broad a topic. I mean it 
covers government classes (very important), geography (semi-important), 
philosophy (very important), culture (not important unless you plan to go 
abroad), family classes (important for most people) and a wealth of other 
subjects. I can't say get rid of them unless you are very specific.

On another note, English classes beyond middle school are pretty much 
useless. I mean great you can answer a bunch of questions on shakespeare 
and iambic pentameter, now tell me how you turn that into a career other 
than English professor? 

Don't get me wrong these are all interesting and worthwhile subjects in and 
of themselves, but they are not important for every career, so why are we 
wasting time, money, and effort teaching them to everyone?﻿
